subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Lexical sets in groups
msgSnippet: Thanks, John, for proposing, advocating, and continuing to explain how lexical sets can serve as a framework for QS. This exercise has only deepened my
messageBody:
Thanks, John, for proposing, advocating, and continuing to explain how
lexical sets can serve as a framework for QS. This exercise has only
deepened my appreciation of the inherent artistry and expressive power
of this alphabet. I think I'm starting to sense the outline of a new
QS manual taking shape.

It seems to me that the decisions you outline may only be determined
in the long run by users who make individual stylistic choices. Some
choices, such as my own choice to use 'Other' instead of 'Thither' (to
use Jon Zuck's nomenclature) are purely aesthetic. Other choices have
an impact on communication across dialects.

I personally don't feel we should be constrained by all of Read's
original choices. Here are my votes for the cases you raise (for my
own accent, West Coast American):

1) SQUARE: use 'Ed' + 'Roar'. (I'm open to persuasion.)
2) NEAR: use 'Eat' + 'Roar'. (I'm open to persuasion.)
3) CURE: use 'Yo-yo' + 'Wool' + 'Roar'. (I'm open to persuasion.)
4) NORTH and FORCE: use 'Oak' + 'Roar'. (I am less open to persuasion.)
5) HAPPY: use 'Eat'. (I'm not open to persuasion.)

I have incorporated these choices into the table that I use when I
write in QS. I haven't polished it up for general distribution, but
here it is anyway:
http://staff.washington.edu/freeman/qs/qs_table_jerome.pdf

Ted


On Nov 6, 2007 5:59 PM, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> I'm proposing a new approach based on grouping the 27 lexical sets into
> different groups and then explaining how to use each group.
>
> Group I: Simple cases
>
> We can unambiguously write KIT with It, DRESS with Et, TRAP with At, STRUT
> with Utter (stressed), COMMA with Utter (unstressed), FOOT with Foot,
> FLEECE with Eat, FACE with Eight, PALM with Ah, GOAT with Owe, GOOSE with
> Ooze, PRICE with I, CHOICE with Oy, and MOUTH with Out. In Australia
> and New Zealand, STRUT is pronounced like a shortened version of PALM.
> However, QS can't represent this distinction, so Ah is used for both.
> As for the New Zealand accent pronouncing KIT like COMMA, it's easy
> for NZ speakersto write It for the stressed vowel and Utter for the
> unstressed one.
>
> Group II: Historic /r/
>
> The lexical sets which involve historic /r/, namely NURSE, START, SQUARE,
> NEAR, NORTH, FORCE, CURE, and LETTER, are always going to be written
> with Roe, so there will never be any *written* merger of these lexical
> sets with any others, even in non-rhotic dialects that don't pronounce
> /r/ in these positions. For example, RP pronounces START like PALM,
> but will write PALM words with Ah and START words with Ah-Roe.
>
> Since there are only eight lexical sets and 15 vowels, there will need
> to be some more or less arbitrary conventions to determine which vowel
> is used to write which set. START, NURSE, and LETTER are unquestionably
> Ah-Roe, Utter-Roe (stressed), and Utter-Roe (unstressed). This is true
> even in accents where LETTER is pronounced like COMMA, because LETTER
> will have a Roe and COMMA will not.
>
> I failed to notice before that Read prescribes Eight-Roe for SQUARE (at
> the bottom of the alphabet page), though Et-Roe would serve as well,
> as the distinction between Eight and Et is neutralized before /r/.
> By analogy, I'd be inclined to write NEAR and CURE with Eat-Roe and
> (Ye-)Ooze-Roe, the historical pronunciations, although It-Roe and
> (Ye-)Foot-Roe would work too for the same reason.
>
> That leaves NORTH and FORCE, which are merged in most accents. However,
> those which still keep them separate use Awe+Roe and Owe+Roe respectively.
> All we have to do, then, is to say that if you pronounce FORCE like
> NORTH, use one (to be decided) for both -- Awe+Roe is the historical
> pronunciation. In some accents, CURE is pronounced like NORTH (and
> FORCE), in which case Awe+Roe is suitable for it.
>
> Group III: BATH and CLOTH
>
> These two lexical sets never correspond to a unique sound: they are always
> merged with something. Either BATH is like TRAP or BATH is like PALM;
> in the former case you write BATH words with At, the same vowel as TRAP
> words; in the latter case, with Ah, the same vowel as PALM words.
>
> CLOTH is analogous: it's either pronounced like LOT or like CLOTH.
>
> Group IV: LOT and THOUGHT
>
> Some accents pronounce LOT separately, in which case Ox is used for it.
> Others pronounce it like PALM, in which case Ah is used. Likewise, some
> accents pronounce THOUGHT separately, in which case Awe is used for it.
> Others pronounce it like PALM, in which case Ah is used. Some merge
> both LOT and THOUGHT with PALM.
>
> GROUP V: HAPPY
>
> Read prescribes It for this, though Eat is much more common (again,
> It and Eat are neutralized in final position, as well as before Ing.
>
> That accounts for all the lexical sets, and explains how to use all
> fifteen QS vowels.
>
> --
> A rabbi whose congregation doesn't want John Cowan
> to drive him out of town isn't a rabbi, http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
> and a rabbi who lets them do it cowan@...
> isn't a man. --Jewish saying
>

Thanks, John, for proposing, advocating, and continuing to explain how
lexical sets can serve as a framework for QS. This exercise has only
deepened my appreciation of the inherent artistry and expressive power
of this alphabet. I think I'm starting to sense the outline of a new
QS manual taking shape.

It seems to me that the decisions you outline may only be determined
in the long run by users who make individual stylistic choices. Some
choices, such as my own choice to use 'Other' instead of 'Thither' (to
use Jon Zuck's nomenclature) are purely aesthetic. Other choices have
an impact on communication across dialects.

I personally don't feel we should be constrained by all of Read's
original choices. Here are my votes for the cases you raise (for my
own accent, West Coast American):

1) SQUARE: use 'Ed' + 'Roar'. (I'm open to persuasion.)
2) NEAR: use 'Eat' + 'Roar'. (I'm open to persuasion.)
3) CURE: use 'Yo-yo' + 'Wool' + 'Roar'. (I'm open to persuasion.)
4) NORTH and FORCE: use 'Oak' + 'Roar'. (I am less open to persuasion.)
5) HAPPY: use 'Eat'. (I'm not open to persuasion.)

I have incorporated these choices into the table that I use when I
write in QS. I haven't polished it up for general distribution, but
here it is anyway:
http://staff.washington.edu/freeman/qs/qs_table_jerome.pdf

Ted


On Nov 6, 2007 5:59 PM, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> I'm proposing a new approach based on grouping the 27 lexical sets into
>  different groups and then explaining how to use each group.
>
>  Group I: Simple cases
>
>  We can unambiguously write KIT with It, DRESS with Et, TRAP with At, STRUT
>  with Utter (stressed), COMMA with Utter (unstressed), FOOT with Foot,
>  FLEECE with Eat, FACE with Eight, PALM with Ah, GOAT with Owe, GOOSE with
>  Ooze, PRICE with I, CHOICE with Oy, and MOUTH with Out. In Australia
>  and New Zealand, STRUT is pronounced like a shortened version of PALM.
>  However, QS can't represent this distinction, so Ah is used for both.
>  As for the New Zealand accent pronouncing KIT like COMMA, it's easy
>  for NZ speakersto write It for the stressed vowel and Utter for the

>
>  Group II: Historic /r/
>
>  The lexical sets which involve historic /r/, namely NURSE, START, SQUARE,
>  NEAR, NORTH, FORCE, CURE, and LETTER, are always going to be written
>  with Roe, so there will never be any *written* merger of these lexical
>  sets with any others, even in non-rhotic dialects that don't pronounce
>  /r/ in these positions. For example, RP pronounces START like PALM,
>  but will write PALM words with Ah and START words with Ah-Roe.
>
>  Since there are only eight lexical sets and 15 vowels, there will need
>  to be some more or less arbitrary conventions to determine which vowel
>  is used to write which set. START, NURSE, and LETTER are unquestionably
>  Ah-Roe, Utter-Roe (stressed), and Utter-Roe (unstressed). This is true

>

>  the bottom of the alphabet page), though Et-Roe would serve as well,
>  as the distinction between Eight and Et is neutralized before /r/.
>  By analogy, I'd be inclined to write NEAR and CURE with Eat-Roe and

>  (Ye-)Foot-Roe would work too for the same reason.

>  That leaves NORTH and FORCE, which are merged in most accents. However,

>
>  Group III: BATH and CLOTH
>
>  These two lexical sets never correspond to a unique sound: they are always
>  merged with something. Either BATH is like TRAP or BATH is like PALM;
>  in the former case you write BATH words with At, the same vowel as TRAP
>  words; in the latter case, with Ah, the same vowel as PALM words.
>
>  CLOTH is analogous: it's either pronounced like LOT or like CLOTH.
>
>  Group IV: LOT and THOUGHT
>
>  Some accents pronounce LOT separately, in which case Ox is used for it.
>  Others pronounce it like PALM, in which case Ah is used. Likewise, some
>  accents pronounce THOUGHT separately, in which case Awe is used for it.
>  Others pronounce it like PALM, in which case Ah is used. Some merge
>  both LOT and THOUGHT with PALM.
>
>  GROUP V: HAPPY
>
>  Read prescribes It for this, though Eat is much more common (again,
>  It and Eat are neutralized in final position, as well as before Ing.
>
>  That accounts for all the lexical sets, and explains how to use all
>  fifteen QS vowels.
